taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Found in ponds (Ref. 11229).  Feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects and plant matter (Ref. 7020).  Aquarium keeping:  in groups of 5 or more individuals; minimum aquarium size 60 cm (Ref. 51539).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: South America:  Lower Paraná River basin and coastal rivers in Uruguay and Brazil.
dataObjects.references: Reis, R.E. 2003 Callichthyidae (Armored catfishes). p. 291-309. In R.E. Reis, S.O. Kullander and C.J. Ferraris, Jr. (eds.) Checklist of the Freshwater Fishes of South and Central America. Porto Alegre: EDIPUCRS, Brasil. (Ref. 37395)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObjects.description: Dorsal spines (total): 1; Dorsal soft rays (total): 8;  Analspines: 0; Analsoft rays: 6

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.references: Reis, R.E. 2003 Callichthyidae (Armored catfishes). p. 291-309. In R.E. Reis, S.O. Kullander and C.J. Ferraris, Jr. (eds.) Checklist of the Freshwater Fishes of South and Central America. Porto Alegre: EDIPUCRS, Brasil. (Ref. 37395)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Procamallanus Infection 33. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Dactylogyrus Gill Flukes Disease. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: The female holds 2-4 eggs between her pelvic fins, where the male fertilizes them for about 30 seconds. Only then the female swims to a suitable spot, where she attaches the very sticky eggs. The pair repeats this process until about 100 eggs have been fertilized and attached (Ref. 1672).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObjects.title: Importance
dataObjects.description: fisheries: of no interest; aquarium: highly commercial
